Literature Review: Bacteriophages (phages) are viruses that infect bacteria, posing significant challenges to the dairy industry by targeting lactic acid bacteria (LAB) used in fermentation processes. The interaction between phages and LAB is a critical area of study, as it directly impacts the efficiency and reliability of dairy fermentations. Recent research has shed light on the mechanisms of phage-host interactions and the evolution of phage resistance in LAB, offering new strategies to mitigate phage-related issues in the dairy industry. Phages infecting LAB are well-documented, with studies focusing on the genetic and molecular basis of these interactions. The coevolution of LAB and phages has led to the development of various defense mechanisms in bacteria, including restriction-modification systems, abortive infection systems, and CRISPR-Cas systems. These mechanisms are encoded either on the bacterial chromosome or on plasmids, influencing the technological approaches for developing phage-resistant starter cultures. The study of phage-host interactions has revealed that phages can rapidly evolve to overcome bacterial defenses, necessitating continuous research and development of new strategies to protect LAB from phage predation. Advances in genomic and molecular biology techniques have facilitated the identification of genes involved in phage resistance, enabling the engineering of robust starter cultures with enhanced resistance to phages. Furthermore, the understanding of phage resistance mechanisms has implications beyond the dairy industry, potentially guiding the development of phage-resistant strains for plant-based fermentations. The dairy industry has adopted various strategies to combat phage infections, including the rotation of starter cultures, the use of phage-resistant mutants, and the application of phage-inhibitory media. These strategies have significantly reduced the impact of phages on dairy fermentations, but the dynamic nature of phage evolution requires ongoing vigilance and innovation. The integration of traditional microbiological methods with modern genomic approaches has provided a comprehensive understanding of phage-host interactions, paving the way for the development of next-generation starter cultures with improved phage resistance. As the demand for fermented products continues to grow, the insights gained from studying phage-host interactions in the dairy industry will be invaluable in ensuring the sustainability and safety of food fermentations. The future of food fermentations, including those involving plant-based alternatives, will likely benefit from the lessons learned in the dairy industry, highlighting the importance of continued research into phage biology and bacterial defense mechanisms.
